title: In a fiction novel, does the narrator reveal his name? - Quora

response.answer_text: In one of the best first-person narratives: Rebecca, by Daphne Du Maurier, the narrator is nameless throughout. (The Rebecca of the title is the first wife, the narrator is the second wife). She is called ‘my love’, and ‘dear’ by her husband, and known as ‘the second Mrs de Winter’ by others - but her first name and maiden name are never revealed. Usually though, the narrator’s name is revealed in narrations of dialogue, eg, ‘She said to me, “Jimmy, that’s just not good enough,” etc. If you don’t reveal the name, it should be for a very good reason: in Rebecca, Du Maurier did it on purpose, because Rebecca was such a strong and powerful personality that even dead she overshadowed the narrator.

It depends. If the book is in first person, that is you're reading what the narrator is going through, the identity might be revealed. But if the book is written in third person, that is, the narrator is narrating someone else's story, the narrator's Identity might not be revealed.
